stories.text:
Sitting in my car after dropping my kid off at school getting noisily massaged by a leaf blower and assaulted by the two-stroke fumes.

Just wondering why these things aren't being phased out more aggressively especially in captain planet country (california) or if it really matters.
stories.title: Ask HN: How much are leaf blowers contributing to climate change?
Supervised Injection Sites for Drug Users to Open in New York City
Recent Progress on the Oil Shell
Hacks Decoded: Seyi Akiwowo, Founder of Glitch

stories.text:
I am looking to learn more about 3d printing and how to create things for my place. I also would like to learn a little about Unity 3d programming.

I am curious what skill you want to learn in the coming year?
stories.title: Ask HN: Skill you want to learn in 2022?

stories.text:
While I was researching existing concepts of most popular apps I realized that most of them took existing concept and flipped it on its head. Maybe I'm wrong for some of them

Snapchat

Existing concept: uploaded images and photos stay online (forever)

Flipped: images and photos stay online shortly

Vine

Existing concept: videos are long

Flipped: videos should be short

Whatsapp

Existing concept: SMS are not free

Flipped: SMS are now free

Twitter

Existing concept: blogs/blogging should have large texts

Flipped: blogs/blogging can be short

Digg

Existing concept: News should be aggregated by journalists

Flipped: news can be aggregated and voted on by visitors

Tinder

Existing concept: dating online is opened for people to send messages to whoever, no matching

Flipped: you need to match in order to continue

These are of course most popular examples. Seems like all of them followed the same formula, probably unintetionally. Of course some of them were lucky, some had good marketing. What's your opinion on it?
stories.title: Flipping existing concepts upside down
UK’s minimum gap for Covid booster jabs to be halved to three months
Elon Musk tells SpaceX employees ‘risk of bankruptcy’
